channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Gaza’s Health Ministry says 40,000 Palestinians have been killed in Israel’s war against Hamas. A full count is elusive.
item.description: The Gaza Health Ministry does not distinguish between civilians and combatants but says the majority of the dead are women and children. Aid workers say the 40,000 figure is likely to be an undercount that excludes thousands of bodies believed to be buried under rubble. About 1,200 people in Israel were killed in Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack, and more than 300 Israeli soldiers have died in combat since late October.

item.title: Gena Rowlands dies at 94. The actress starred in ‘A Woman Under the Influence’ and ‘The Notebook.’
item.description: Over seven decades, Rowlands worked sparingly in mainstream fare but managed to attract a cascade of superlatives and an honorary Academy Award for career achievement in 2015.

item.title: Columbia President Minouche Shafik resigns after drawing ire over response to pro-Palestinian protests
item.description: The resignation ends a short and turbulent tenure marred by controversy and backlash over how she handled an outbreak of protests on campus last spring.

item.title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. tried to meet with Kamala Harris to discuss endorsing her in exchange for a Cabinet job
item.description: Harris has rebuffed the outreach, while Kennedy has had conversations with Republican nominee Donald Trump about a role in his administration as well. Kennedy is exploring multiple options for the future of his presidential effort, which has seen a decline in national polling since President Joe Biden dropped out of the race.

item.title: A Stonehenge mystery has (maybe) been solved, but the revelation raises tantalizing new questions
item.description: Researchers on Wednesday revealed that the long-mysterious “Altar Stone” at the heart of Stonehenge came from faraway Scotland, leading scientists to question how — and why — a six-ton slab of sandstone made its way from north to south 5,000 years ago.

item.title: Trump vs. Harris magnifies America’s generational and cultural divides
item.description: “Make America Great Again” versus “We are not going back.” Lee Greenwood’s music versus Beyoncé’s. The two candidates, their rallies and their movements are showcasing two sides of the country split by demographics and cultural touchstones — not just party and policy.

item.title: WHO declares a global health emergency as a new form of mpox spreads rapidly in Africa
item.description: Cases in Africa have already surpassed 15,000 this year, exceeding the toll for all of 2023. Two years ago, mpox emerged as a threat in the United States as cases surged mainly among gay men.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: How to ditch sister’s ‘insufferable’ guy without hurting feelings
item.description: Carolyn Hax: How to ditch sister’s ‘insufferable’ guy without hurting feelings

item.title: Happening now: Our food critic is telling the story of the time he judged Tim Walz’s hot dish
item.description: Happening now: Our food critic is telling the story of the time he judged Tim Walz’s hot dish

item.title: Congress declined to create a national monument to recognize the 1908 Springfield race riot. Now Biden will do it on his own.
item.description: The president will make the designation during a Friday event with civil rights leaders and Illinois lawmakers, the White House confirmed to The Washington Post on Wednesday. More than a century after the 1908 race riot sparked the founding of the NAACP, Springfield is reeling from the fatal shooting of Sonya Massey, an unarmed Black woman, by an Illinois sheriff’s deputy.

item.title: Today’s On the Record is inspired by a kangaroo
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: The annual inflation rate dropped in July, probably keeping the Fed on track to cut interest rates next month
item.description: A string of encouraging reports on prices have bolstered the central bank’s confidence that it can take some pressure off the economy before it slows down too much.

item.title: Tim Walz. Primary results. Weapons to Israel. Ohio murder. Tropical storm. Parvovirus. Message in a bottle. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida, mired in record-low approval ratings, says he will stand down next month
item.description: Kishida, who has ramped up Japan's defense spending and hewn closely with the United States on security matters, will not seek reelection as head of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party next month, bringing to an end his three-year tenure as prime minister.

item.title: Ex-police chief who led raid on Kansas newspaper faces felony charge of obstruction of justice amid investigation of his department
item.description: Gideon Cody allegedly tampered with an investigation into his force’s raid of the Marion County Record newsroom and its publisher’s home in a case that sparked national outrage from press freedom advocates.

item.title: An Israeli raid deep inside Gaza rescued four hostages but killed scores of Palestinians. A review of videos shows how it happened.
item.description: A Washington Post video investigation of the June 8 raid in Nuseirat shows the Israeli military employed heavy airstrikes for nearly four hours in the dense residential area where Hamas was holding the captives. The raid, which left 274 people dead according to Palestinian authorities, was the most successful hostage-rescue operation of the war.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: When his partner gets sick, boyfriend makes a show of being sicker
item.description: Carolyn Hax: When his partner gets sick, boyfriend makes a show of being sicker

item.title: This oil tycoon brings in tens of millions for Trump, and he’s telling Trump what the industry wants
item.description: Harold Hamm has become the former president’s point person in raising money from oil industry donors. He is also relaying to Trump what the industry is seeking: less environmental regulation.

item.title: Near, far, wherever you are, I believe that it’s time for today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Hack investigation. Musk and Trump. Ukraine. Abortion lawsuit. Greece fire. Disputed bronze medal. Spinning iceberg. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Donald Trump’s interview with Elon Musk on X delayed by technical difficulties
item.description: The former president’s interview was scheduled to begin at 8 p.m. Eastern time, but has been delayed by at least 20 minutes due to unknown technical difficulties. Musk previously interviewed Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis on X when DeSantis announced his primary challenge to Trump, and the website faced similar issues that prevented people from being able to join the call between the two men. Musk blamed a “massive” denial of service attack on the website for the problems.

item.title: Biden-Harris campaign advisers and a Trump ally were allegedly targeted by Iranian hackers, FBI probe finds
item.description: The FBI investigation began in June after Roger Stone's email was allegedly compromised and hackers attempted to break into the accounts of Democratic presidential campaign advisers, people familiar with the matter say.

item.title: Iran, wary of war, weighs retaliation against Israel for the assassination of Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh
item.description: In public, Iranian officials are continuing to warn of a “tough” reprisal to “punish” Israel. But in private meetings with the leaders of its armed proxies, according to those familiar with the conversations, Iran has called for caution — seeking to balance any show of force with the desire to avoid an all-out war in the region.

item.title: FBI says it is investigating the alleged hack of sensitive Trump campaign materials
item.description: The GOP campaign claimed this weekend that it had been hacked by Iran, in an echo of past battles over foreign nations’ interference in U.S. presidential elections.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Surprise half-siblings are living reminders of father’s infidelity
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Surprise half-siblings are living reminders of father’s infidelity

item.title: Painting a zoo in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Trump hack. Rally crowds. Gaza strike. Uvalde videos. Boeing woes. Allergy spray. Tom Cruise. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: The Olympics needed a reset. Merci to Paris for providing it, columnist Barry Svrluga writes.
item.description: After lackluster Olympics in Tokyo and Beijing and disappointing hosts even before the coronavirus pandemic, these Summer Games were exactly what the whole enterprise needed and in a style no other city could provide, Svrluga writes.

item.title: After two years of far-right rule in a Michigan county, the opposition had one chance to change it
item.description: Divisive, Trump-style politics came to Ottawa County. Then moderate Republicans and some Democrats mobilized and fought back.

item.title: Trump’s plan to upend the federal workforce could rattle the DMV economy
item.description: The Republican presidential nominee’s Agenda47 policy manifesto and his party platform seek to “shatter the Deep State” with actions such as moving up to 100,000 federal positions out of D.C., which experts say could be devastating to the area’s economy. Virginia, Maryland and D.C. are among the top four jurisdictions nationwide for federal civilian employees.

item.title: Day 16 highlights from Paris Olympics: Team USA wraps up Games tied with China in gold medals and atop total medal count
item.description: Sunday’s win over France in the women’s basketball final gave the United States a 40th gold, enough to finish the competition even with China. Team USA’s 126 medals overall easily topped China’s 91. American gymnast Jordan Chiles must return her bronze medal from the women’s floor exercise. And Dutch distance runner Sifan Hassan won the women’s marathon in Olympic record time.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: U.S. women’s basketball team, trailing in second half, comes back to beat host France and capture eighth straight Olympic gold
item.description: One of the Olympics’ greatest dynasties was tested Sunday. But the United States survived and has now won 10 of 13 Olympic women’s basketball tournaments.

item.title: Can you reduce your risk of cancer? Here’s what an oncologist with a family history of diagnoses does.
item.description: Taking sun protection seriously is one of this doctor’s five tips to prevent a cancer diagnosis.

item.title: The U.S. women’s basketball team takes on host France for its eighth straight Olympic gold. Follow our coverage.
item.description: Team USA, the heavy favorite, is on a 60-game winning streak in the Olympics and looking to make it back-to-back wins for American men’s and women’s basketball over the French. This is France’s second appearance in a gold medal game.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: U.S. gymnast Jordan Chiles must return her Olympic bronze medal for floor after court ruling
item.description: Chiles won her medal Monday after a coach’s inquiry lifted her over Romania’s Ana Barbosu, but the Court of Arbitration for Sport ruled Saturday that the inquiry that benefited Chiles was filed after the one-minute deadline. The International Olympic Committee confirmed Sunday morning that the medal would be reallocated to Barbosu.

item.title: Trump campaign says it is the victim of a foreign hack after the leak of a report on Vance
item.description: Microsoft discovered evidence that Iranian hackers compromised the email account of a former Trump campaign adviser, a person familiar with the matter says.

item.title: Day 15 highlights from Paris Olympics: U.S. track and field stands out behind stars Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone, Gabby Thomas and Rai Benjamin
item.description: Benjamin's huge anchor leg ensured the men's 4x400 team the victory. On the women's side, McLaughlin-Levrone ran away from everyone on the second leg, and Thomas followed suit en route to an easy win. Also on the track, American Masai Russell brought home gold in the women's 100-meter hurdles. And elsewhere, the U.S. women's soccer and men's basketball teams added golds of their own.

item.title: U.S. men’s basketball team beats host France, capturing gold for the fifth straight Olympics
item.description: Led by aging stars LeBron James, Steph Curry and Kevin Durant, the Americans went 6-0 in the Paris Games and captured gold in front of rabid French fans in central Paris. The Americans last failed to win gold in 2004.

item.title: The U.S. men take on Victor Wembanyama and host nation France in a battle for Olympic hoops gold. Follow our coverage.
item.description: Team USA was the tournament’s favorite. Backed by rabid fans, France has notched multiple upsets along the way. Now the teams will battle for gold in Paris.

item.title: U.S. women’s soccer team beats Brazil, 1-0, to capture its first Olympic gold medal since 2012
item.description: Mallory Swanson scored the winning goal in the 57th minute. With a new coach and new-look roster, the Americans stormed through the Olympic tournament undefeated.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: I feel pressured by my family’s hopes for my future partner
item.description: Ask Sahaj: I feel pressured by my family’s hopes for my future partner

item.title: The U.S. women’s soccer team, seeking its first Olympic gold since 2012, is set to take on Brazil in Paris. Follow our coverage.
item.description: Led by a new cohort of young stars, the Americans have stormed through the tournament undefeated after a disappointing World Cup last year.

item.title: A pastor claimed his pro-Trump prophecies came from God. His brother called him a fake.
item.description: Jeremiah Johnson found religious fame after leaning into politics. His brother, also a preacher, worried he was twisting the Lord’s word for money and power.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Frank Zappa’s kids are still grappling with his legacy — and each other
item.description:
Dweezil no longer speaks to his siblings. Moon has spent decades reassessing the family dynamic — emotional labor that lies thick on the pages of her new memoir.
Ahmet and Diva, meanwhile, seem dazed still by the force of their siblings’ anger — siblings with whom they share not just a fraught business partnership but also a one-of-a-kind childhood.

item.title: Day 14 highlights from Paris Olympics: American Rai Benjamin rules the track; U.S. women’s basketball will play for gold
item.description: Benjamin breezed to a gold medal in the men's 400-meter hurdles and helped erase the foibles of the U.S. men's 4x100 relay team, which finished seventh and was eventually disqualified because of a bad first baton exchange. Elsewhere, the U.S. women smothered Australia on the basketball court, ensuring a trip to their eighth straight gold medal game, where they will meet France on Sunday.

item.title: FDA rejects first psychedelic to treat PTSD, marking a setback and calling for more study of ecstasy-based drug
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration declined to approve MDMA to treat post-traumatic stress disorder, instead calling for another large study that could take years to complete.

item.title: Imane Khelif, female boxer who was a target of online attacks over ‘gender eligibility’ test, wins Olympic gold
item.description: The Algerian fighter faced online hate after a Russia-linked boxing organization disqualified her from last year's world championships.
